pullRequest.body:
Because the distance is not homogeneous

nodes.body:
### PR summary [188400c598](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/22810/commits/188400c598943f9704289e1473f114c9a2965cf3)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.PiNat`|-1350|
| `Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.PiNat.Basic`|1350|
| `Mathlib.Topology.MetricSpace.PiNat.Normed` (new file)|1370|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ PiCountable.not_dist_homogeneous'`
`+ dist_homogeneous`
`+ dist_translation_invariant`
`+ norm_single`
`+ not_all_dist_induced_by_norm`
`++ normedAddCommGroup`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

I find it hard to tell precisely what this counterexample is intended to be counter-exemplifying. 

There are inclusions (metric spaces) ‚äá (normed add groups) ‚äá (normed modules over a normed ring). Which of these two inclusions are you trying to show is not an equality?

In this particular case, we have `[Module ‚Ñù (‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñù)]`, a normed add comm group that is a module over a normed ring, but they do not give a normed module structure. I could make the counterexample state:
```
theorem not_all_dist_induced_by_norm : ¬¨ ‚àÄ (ùïú E : Type)
    [NormedRing ùïú] [NormedAddCommGroup E] [Module ùïú E], BoundedSMul ùïú E := by
```

What would be your suggestion at how to clarify what is being counter-exemplified?

> I could make the counterexample state:
```
theorem not_all_dist_induced_by_norm : ¬¨ ‚àÄ (ùïú E : Type)
    [NormedRing ùïú] [NormedAddCommGroup E] [Module ùïú E], BoundedSMul ùïú E := by
```
Why would one expect that to be true in the first place? Without any assumption relating the topologies of `ùïú` and `E`, there's no reason to expect any compatibility.

> What would be your suggestion at how to clarify what is being counter-exemplified?

The point of this example (IMHO) is that it is a topological vector space, and the topology is locally convex and metrizable, but there is no normed-space structure which induces this topology. But that is a far stronger statement than showing that *some particular choice of metric* inducing that topology is not induced by a norm. (It is trivial to find examples of metrics on a normed space which are not themselves norms, but induce the same topology as the norm.)

Thanks, that's enlightening. My interpretation of your statement was
```
theorem not_all_dist_induced_by_norm : ¬¨ ‚àÄ (ùïú E : Type)
    [NormedLinearOrderedField ùïú]
    [NormedAddCommGroup E]
    [Module ùïú E]
    [LocallyConvexSpace ùïú E]
    [ContinuousSMul ùïú E],
    BoundedSMul ùïú E
     := by
```
If I need to be more specific about some part of this, please let me know -- I get lost in how to refer how one typeclass induces a different one. In particular, I couldn't make this work easily with `MetrizableSpace`.

Separately, this uncovered that we were missing these instances:
```
example : LocallyConvexSpace NNReal NNReal
```
and a way to define `LocallyConvexSpace Real Real` without referring to NormedSpaces
Is Damiano really the copyright holder without being the author?
I think this and the instance above should be in mathlib proper, since the metric space instance is?
The metric space instance is a def. Do you want me to do the `local instance` in the `PiNat` file?
Yes, exactly. (or use `letI`)
`Normed*` isn't imported in the `PiNat` file. Would you like a separate file made?
Yes, a new file sounds good.
This ends up a little tidier if you don't `push_neg` in your head, since on foralls you can use typeclass binders and drop all one inferInstances
Is this used?

```suggestion
attribute [local instance] PiCountable.metricSpace
```
should work too
I think this lemma belongs in the new mathlib file too
I think this should be a `have`, since it is immediately superseded by the instance below
This probably belongs in `Analysis/Normed/PiNat.lean`

pullRequest.title: feat(Counterexamples): metric space not induced by norm

The point of this example (IMHO) is that it is a topological vector space, and the topology is locally convex and metrizable, but there is no normed-space structure which induces this topology. But that is a far stronger statement than showing that *some particular choice of metric* inducing that topology is not induced by a norm. (It is trivial to find examples of metrics on a normed space which are not themselves norms, but induce the same topology as the norm.)

Thanks, that's enlightening. My interpretation of your statement was
```
theorem not_all_dist_induced_by_norm : ¬¨ ‚àÄ (ùïú E : Type)
    [NormedLinearOrderedField ùïú]
    [NormedAddCommGroup E]
    [Module ùïú E]
    [LocallyConvexSpace ùïú E]

    BoundedSMul ùïú E
```

source.title: feat(Topology/.../LocallyConvex): locally convex over self for linearly ordered semirings
